description: My thoughts and observations about everything and anything

trongate.summary:
Trongate is often misunderstood and gets a bad reputation because it breaks with common standards and takes a journey back to its roots.
In this article, I will explore and highlight this rough diamond that deserves a spot in the limelight.
trongate.intro: An exciting PHP framework that challenges the established standards and offers a simple yet effective approach to development.
trongate.tagline:
I have worked with PHP for {{phpExpYears}} years, and one recurring thing is unnecessary code that needs maintenance.
Occam's razor is clearly visible when all you want is to tear everything out by the roots and start fresh, hoping to build something more simple.
trongate.mhavc: This is where Trongate shines; you get a simple starting point with a solid starting architecture due to everything being divided into modules, including media and JavaScript files.
trongate.missing_i18n:
A criticism that could be made is that internationalization (i18n) hasn't been considered, and there is actually no real language support.
This is true and something I have previously addressed. It's on the roadmap, and I look forward to seeing how it gets resolved. :)
trongate.callback_validation: Another feature that often flies under the radar is <u>callback</u> based validation.
trongate.hope: My hope with this article is to spark people's interest and highlight a rough diamond that unfortunately has gained a somewhat bad reputation.
trongate.before_i_go: Before I go, I just want to shout out
trongate.mx: A library based on <htmx-link>HTMX</htmx-link> and in many ways has the same features, just using mx- instead of hx-.
trongate.mx_more: And yet it offers so much more, with close integration, built-in modal support, <mx-during-request>"optimistic" UI</mx-during-request>, and <mx-after-swap>more.</mx-after-swap>
